ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned lots of interesting things about Chinese culture, grammar, new vocab and grammar
I developed my Chinese speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills during this course. I also was able to reflect on my Chinese heritage and how it has affected my life.
Lots of chinese speaking, reading and writing practice.

I learned how to formulate my thoughts into coherent paragraph structure and eventually longer essays in Chinese. Throughout the year, chapters centered around a specific topic such as Chinese dining decorum or the obesity epidemic. This allowed us to learn subject-specific vocabulary that could be used in everyday dialogue.
Working on presentations and essays greatly improved my speaking and writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: StrengthsChen lao shi is very engaged and is always willing to help. I learned a lot.

Strengths include the attention to level of understanding for each individual student. Chen Laoshi tried to engaged every student during the class, and adjust to each students strength and weaknesses. For instance, she would call on those who struggle more with intonation to read the passages more frequently.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wished there was an in-person aspect of engagement to the class. This couldve included games from a third-party application or video recordings of some sort as an assignment. Much of the work centered around using a laptop and staring at a screen, that I felt the quality of learning couldve been improved with more outside-the-box activities.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you need to fill your language requirement or are genuinely interested in learning Chinese and connecting more with your Chinese side as a Chinese-American. This class is a lot of work so be prepared to consistently spend an hour or two a day on reading quizzes, dictation, homeworks, studying for tests, essays, oral recordings, etc. Chen Lao Shi is super nice, helpful, and a fantastic teacher. Her slides are amazing and if you pay attention, you will more than equipped to learn a lot and do well. This is also a great way to forge a connection with other Chinese-American students and bond over our similar experiences. This was super practical stuff I was able to export in my own life with my family.
Yes! Chen lao shi is amazing.

Yes! This course is very intensive, but you learn so many characters and aspects of Chinese culture. The class discussions are very enjoyable as well because the teachers create a calm but fun environment.
Yes! Great for any student interested in Mandarin, particularly regarding reading and grammer.

Yes, I think if you want to learn Chinese as either a complete non-Heritage novice or a heritage student who only knows a couple of phrases and sentence. It doesnt matter what level you start at because you will definitely improve by the end of the year! And visiting Asia anytime afterwards will make this experience all the more worth it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were at times virtual discussions.
